msgSnippet: George, Ah, that s a good reason. In my case, it doesn t apply as strictly because of what I m doing in the TestSetup.setUp(). I have a set of database inserts

Subject: RE: [junit] TestSetup decorator with swingui.TestRunner
To: junit@yahoogroups.com

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
From: Herm Greider <animate123@...>

George,

Ah, that's a good reason. In my case, it doesn't 
apply as strictly because of what I'm doing
in the TestSetup.setUp(). I have a set of database 
inserts that I do in the TestSetup.setup(), but don't 
delete the rows in the tearDown(). Because I don't 
delete the data, I can use it in the individual tests.

So, I'm really breaking the rules by not cleaning up 
what I did in the setUp().

Suppose I could just do the database init externally 
anyway.

BTW, I do have separate setUp and tearDown for each 
individual test case wrapped by the TestSetup. That 
makes it possible to do additional setup for the 
individual tests. 

Thanks,
Herm

--- "Dinwiddie, George"
<George.Dinwiddie@...> wrote:
> Herm,
> 
> One thing I've found is that when using the
> TestSetup
> decorator, it's no longer possible to run the
> individual
> tests, because there's no longer an individual setUp
> and
> tearDown for them.
> 
>  - George
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Herm Greider [mailto:animate123@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, March 07, 2001 11:49 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] TestSetup decorator with
> swingui.TestRunner
> 
> 
> A couple of kind folks aimed me at the TestSetup 
> decorator a couple of weeks ago to run setup code 
> for a block of tests. 
> 
> This works great except for one annoyance. In the
> swingui.TestRunner, under the Test Hierarchy tab,
> the TestSetup and the tests it wraps show up as:
> 
>     junit.framework.TestSuite
> 
> With no drill-down possible. Is this by design?
> 
> It is really nothing more than an annoyance. But
> it would be nice to be able to run the complete 
> TestSuite and then pick specific tests from the
> hierarchy tab and run them directly to isolate 
> failures without starting a separate GUI.
> 
> Herm Greider
> Lexis-Nexis
> Dayton, Ohio
> 
>
